Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Repeated COVID-19 Vaccination Strategies in Kidney Transplant Recipients

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as a multicenter, open-label, randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: in kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) who exhibited poor serological responses after 2 or 3 doses of an mRNA-based vaccine

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive a single dose of mRNA-1273 (100 μg, n=25), a double dose of mRNA-1273 (2×100 μg, n=25), or a single dose of Ad26.COV2.S (n=25)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the efficacy of various repeated COVID-19 vaccination strategies in kidney transplant recipients

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in SARS-CoV-2-specific interleukin-21 memory T-cell and B-cell responses, measured 28 days post-vaccination

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Result_Outcome.evidence: Repeated vaccination increased the seroconversion rate from 21% to 66%, significantly associated with enhanced levels of SARS-CoV-2-specific interleukin-21 memory T cells (odds ratio, 3.84 [1.89-7.78]; P<0.001) and B cells (odds ratio, 35.93 [6.94-186.04]; P<0.001)

Funding.evidence: Supported by the Dutch Renal patients COVID-19 VACcination consortium
